description: From Middle English rife, from Old English rīfe, rȳfe (“rife, abundant, frequent”), from Proto-Germanic *rībaz (“generous”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁reyp- (“to tear (off), rip”). Cognate with West Frisian rju (“rife, much”), Low German rive (“abundant, munificent”), Dutch rijf (“abundant, copious”), Icelandic rífr (“rife, munificent”), Icelandic reifa (“to bestow”).

entries.meaning: Widespread, common, prevalent, current (mainly of unpleasant or harmful things).
examples: Smallpox was rife after the siege had been lifted.

entries.meaning: Abounding; present in large numbers, plentiful.
examples: These woodlands are rife with red deer.

entries.meaning: Full of (mostly unpleasant or harmful things).
examples: Many post-colonial governments were rife with lawlessness and corruption.
What! I am rife a little yet.

adverbs.description: rife (comparative more rife, superlative most rife)

examples: The snowdrops grow rife on the slopes of Mount Pembroke.
